thread.title: Burned by flaming water skis? Your doctor has a code for that
thread.title_full: Burned by flaming water skis? Your doctor has a code for that - seattlepi.com

author: seattlepi.com
title: Burned by flaming water skis? Your doctor has a code for that
text:
After one week under a new, federally mandated system of medical diagnostic codes known as the ICD-10, no doctor has apparently filed a V97.33.
V97.33 is the new code for "sucked into a jet engine."
The ICD-10, which went into effect last week, assigns alphanumeric codes to some 70,000 diseases and injuries, up from the 14,000 in the previous set of codes. Some of the ailments and injuries are so specific that they seem ridiculous, such as being vacuumed up by a jet engine, burned by fiery water skis or the famous W56.22 — "struck by an orca," which became the title of a illustrated book of odd ICD-10 codes.
We've include some of those and other favorites of ours in the above slide show.
Health care providers have dreaded the new system because of the work involved.
Do you suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome? Your doctor must figure out which of nine codes apply to your condition. Failure to use the right code or mismatching a diagnosis and procedural code can result in an insurer rejecting the claim.
No wonder physicians are ready to pull out their hair, which, by the way, has its own code — F63.3.
Medical professionals have vented about the hardship of the switchover on social media, some even putting up mock horror decorations similar to Halloween displays.
